title: Václav Zítek
text:
Václav Zítek (24 March 1932 – 18 December 2011) was a <a href="Czech%20Republic">Czech</a> <a href="opera">opera</a> singer. A <a href="lyric%20baritone">lyric baritone</a> with a beautiful timbre and a wide <a href="vocal%20range">vocal range</a>, he was one of the leading Czech singers of the postwar generation. He particularly excelled in portraying <a href="Leo%C5%A1%20Jan%C3%A1%C4%8Dek">Janáček</a> and <a href="Bed%C5%99ich%20Smetana">Smetana</a> heroes. His voice is preserved on numerous opera recordings made with the <a href="Supraphon">Supraphon</a> record label.
Biography.
Born in <a href="Tis%C3%A1">Tisá</a>, Zítek studied singing privately with E. Matoušková, M. Linka, D. Levytský, and <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Otava">Zdeněk Otava</a>. Between 1955 and 1959, he worked on the staff at the <a href="National%20Theatre%20%28Prague%29">National Theatre</a> in <a href="Prague">Prague</a> and sang in some smaller roles. In 1959–1960, he worked as a principal artist at the <a href="Zden%C4%9Bk%20Nejedl%C3%BD%20Theatre">Zdeněk Nejedlý Theatre</a> in <a href="Ostrava">Ostrava</a>. He then was a leading baritone at the opera house in <a href="%C3%9Ast%C3%AD%20nad%20Labem">Ústí nad Labem</a> from 1960 to 1969. While there he also appeared occasionally as a guest artist at the Prague National Theatre. He eventually left Ústí nad Labem for that house, singing as a leading baritone at the National Theatre from 1969 through 1991.
Among Zítek's signature roles are several parts in operas by <a href="Bed%C5%99ich%20Smetana">Bedřich Smetana</a>, including Kalina in "<a href="The%20Secret%20%28opera%29">The Secret</a>", Tomeš in "<a href="The%20Kiss%20%28opera%29">The Kiss</a>", Vladislav in "<a href="Dalibor%20%28opera%29">Dalibor</a>", Lord Vok in "<a href="The%20Devil%27s%20Wall">The Devil's Wall</a>", and Přemysl in "<a href="Libu%C5%A1e%20%28opera%29">Libuše</a>"; the latter of which he sang for the reopening of the Prague National Theater in 1983. He is also known for the role of Prince Vasilij Šujský in <a href="Anton%C3%ADn%20Dvo%C5%99%C3%A1k">Antonín Dvořák</a>'s "<a href="Dimitrij%20%28opera%29">Dimitrij</a>" and for several <a href="Leo%C5%A1%20Jan%C3%A1%C4%8Dek">Janáček</a> heroes, including Stárek in "<a href="Jen%C5%AFfa">Jenůfa</a>", Forester in "<a href="The%20Cunning%20Little%20Vixen">The Cunning Little Vixen</a>", and Baron Jaroslav Prus in "<a href="The%20Makropulos%20Affair%20%28opera%29">The Makropulos Affair</a>". His recording of the role of Alexandr Petrovič Gorjančikov in Janáček's "<a href="From%20the%20House%20of%20the%20Dead">From the House of the Dead</a>" won the <a href="Grammy%20Award%20for%20Best%20Opera%20Recording">Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording</a> in 1982. Other roles in his repertory include Count Almaviva in "<a href="The%20Marriage%20of%20Figaro">The Marriage of Figaro</a>", the title role in "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>", Escamillo in "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>", and the title hero in "<a href="Eugene%20Onegin%20%28opera%29">Eugene Onegin</a>".
Zítek's appearances on the international stage include performances at the <a href="Bolshoi%20Theatre">Bolshoi Theatre</a>, the <a href="Grand%20Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre%20de%20Bordeaux">Grand Théâtre de Bordeaux</a>, the <a href="Romanian%20National%20Opera%2C%20Bucharest">Romanian National Opera, Bucharest</a>, and at the <a href="Berlin%20State%20Opera">State Opera</a>, <a href="Deutsche%20Oper%20Berlin">Deutsche Oper</a>, and <a href="Komische%20Oper%20Berlin">Komische Oper</a> in <a href="Berlin">Berlin</a>. In 1988 he had a major triumph singing Alexandr Petrovič Gorjančikov with the <a href="Op%C3%A9ra%20National%20de%20Paris">Opéra National de Paris</a>. In 1985 Zítek was made a <a href="People%27s%20Artist%20of%20the%20%C4%8CSSR">People's Artist of the ČSSR</a>. In 2007 he was honored with a <a href="Thalia%20Award">Thalia Award</a>. He died in Prague, aged 79.
